cons: The only con Is the low stipend, which is about 24 k for the year 2021-2022, but the PhD students are unionized now (August 2022) and a revaluation of the stipend is coming ahead.

pros: Really nice and friendly and inclusive culture
cons: Lack of Tech knowledge in the common people

pros:
Flexibility, autonomy


The work/life balance, flexibility, and no micromanaging are some of the good things though.
cons:
Management, heathcare, technology, budget, expertise


If you're IT, this is not the place for you, unless you really love the (lean) higher education culture.

They like to squeeze the duties of 2 or 3 people into one position (to save money). Many end up being stretched extremely thin, which leads to very slow progress, lower priority items on the back burner, and some falling through the cracks. This also leads to poor management and mentorship & employee deployment that hardly exists.

The culture is reactive. They are behind their peers when investing in IT, and only make those investments when an event blows up in their face and costs them money. 

They're still using the old decentralized model for IT & policy management. This means every department has autonomy to do as they see fit, and policy & administrative controls are very relaxed. This makes policy enforcement very difficult and deficient technical controls. This leads to high risk IT practices, and very difficult training management.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant & Graduate Teaching Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: Friendly environment, Easy going, Helpful faculty
cons: Small department, not many option to explore

pros: The people are generally kind and good hearted. There are opportunities to add skills to your resume and gain a broad width of experience. Students and graduates want to change the world - and some do!
cons: Poor facilities for many. (Mice, bugs and bats are a daily occurrence in some buildings.) Department and office politics are the norm. Strategic leadership is lacking. Faculty and administrators are often at odds. Good ideas get mired in committees so that only watered down ideas survive. Everyone is doing two or three jobs, and open vacancies go for months before being filled. Well known that HR discourages promotions and prefers to hire in. The employee review process is a sham, and salaries are running joke. The raise this year for top performers was less than cost of living.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: The school has authentically caring faculty and front-line employees. Staff is amazingly agile given slim resources.
cons: Research and Teaching assistance ships are brutal, and among underpaying the students immensely, the infrastructure at the school is so poor that RAs and TAs lack working computers, software, or any good tools to do their jobs. However, Investment decisions made by senior management seem micro-managed and parsimonious. Sidewalks are broken, computers don’t work, but the President wants to build a new gate. It’s depressing how much staff has to put up with here, and not surprising that many become bitter over the years.

pros: Great hardworking students in a university dedicated to its education. Students benefit from small class sizes as well as discussion sessions with teaching assistants to further understand the class material.  There is also great diversity to the campus which enables the students to share opinions and be comfortable with sharing.  Also, due to the small campus size, it is easy to interact with students outside of the classroom environment.
cons: There are not many downsides of working at Clark University.  The area that Clark is in is not the best area of Worcester but as in any urban city, as long as you are careful you will be fine.

pros: The workers are friendly and fun to be around. I thought the wages are reasonable. There aren't many hours available, but that's ok as this is really a work study job.
cons: I think that the email system is flawed. People on campus and professors will be notified of their packages arrival at too early a date or time, which leads to a lot of complaints from the faculty and students. Other than this, I like what is being done.

pros: I was working on a side-project of a professor.  My manager was incredibly understanding of my position at the time-- college graduate who was having trouble finding work and needed to build his resume.  She let me take on just about any responsibility or aspect of the project that I felt would be beneficial to my future work search.  I eventually decided to attend graduate school, and I fully believe her recommendation was one of the key reasons I was accepted.
cons: None.  This was a rather informal relationship to start, but grew and developed steadily as we mutually found a good role for me in the project.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: Great community. Professors are willing to let you grow into your teaching ability by providing guidance, but letting you take lead after you become more comfortable.  Diverse student population is very fun to work with.
cons: The stipend is below average for the area and schools of similar size, but the university has taken steps in the last few years to begin remedying it.

pros: Flexible hours, working closely to dedicated staff, opportunities to take on more responsibilities if desired. As a student, I really enjoyed getting to work and support a department I loved.
cons: This was a pretty flexible a casual job setting. Certain resources weren't available to me as an assistant, like a personal work place, an office phone, printer, etc. I had to make it work with personal resources and sometimes on my own time.

review_title: The Pros and Cons of Working at Clark University
pros: Wonderful people and a great mission and place. Generally a very accepting community. Lots of opportunities to learn and stretch your skills, attend free educational events, and get involved.
cons: Doesn't pay well. Can at times be a very political environment and offers very little by way of training or mentoring employees towards advancing their careers.

pros: Flexible time and good payment if you have certain experiences in sound and lighting setup - which is not a hard skill to acquire.
cons: Your first year of work would be sort of boring since they will not assign well paid projects to newbie. My advice is to try to shadow the former techs as much as possible.

pros: I received a great education for my field and was able to get a great job not long afterwards.
cons: The education style is old-fashioned where faculty are overworked, not compensated very fairly, and prioritize their efforts on excelling students while leaving struggling students behind.

review_title: A Great Joy to Work at Clark!
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Worcester, MA
pros: Afforded autonomy in carrying out the duties of the role, numerous opportunities for leadership and skill development, travel is great (domestic and international - 3 months out of the year), vibrant community of professionals, academics and students, 4 weeks vacation.
cons: The pay was low compared to comparable jobs at other universities - though Worcester is very affordable so it kind of balances out.

pros: they have a supportive faculty really ready to help you discharge your duties without hesitation. Being a small community of intellectuals, the atmosphere for excellence is consistently encouraging.
cons: The library is not too resourceful for research and that makes research sometimes difficult . The neighboring community is sometimes not too safe. the streets are not safe for late working hours

review_title: Career service needs to be better
pros: The diversity really makes Clark University a different campus. The people are friendly and down-to-earth. There is no pressure for you to act in a certain way.
cons: The courses are not challenging enough. Library and LEEP Center don't seem to be very resourceful.

job_title: GIS Research Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: Great people, great team, I learned a lot from working as a research assistant, since everyone was involved in the process, I have a very clear idea of the whole project and the objectives of each step.
cons: Besides focusing solely on the project, team members are also professors and scientists which might make some meetings canceled or not completed.

pros: The physics department is really small. Everyone knows each other and it is really fun to work, since your professors are very easy going, and you have most of the control in your research.the research topics are a lot.
cons: There are very few/ none cons of working at Clark. The salary is adequate.

pros: I got the opportunity to manage 15 student employees and it helped me to develop my leadership skills.
cons: It was a little challenging to cope with classes and work duties sometimes during the mid-term and final exam.

pros: The culture of Clark University is wonderful, and the people who work here are incredible.
cons: Safety around the university isn't really what anyone would like it to be. Many people don't feel safe walking to their cars or homes at night.
